_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing
Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Drexel Chemical Company, 2400 Pier Street, Memphis, TN

RMP Facility ID 100000202194

5 Year Update



Drexel Chemicals stores anhydrous ammonia and monoisopropylamine (70%) (MIPA) at the facility in an amount that exceeds the threshold established by EPA for Risk Management Planning. Drexel Chemical believes that risks associated with anhydrous ammonia and MIPA storage at this facility are well managed.



SOURCE AND PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Drexel produces agricultural chemicals.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored in one aboveground storage tank at the facility and is used in the nitrogenous slow release plant food process.  The MIPA is stored in one aboveground storage tank at the facility and is used in the glyphosate formulation process.  Both tanks are located in a secondary containment dike.



Overall responsibility for the RMP for the nitrogenous slow release plant food process and glyphosate formulation process is assigned to the Plant Manager.  Employees are responsible for following the requirements of this policy.  Employees are encouraged to actively participate in the PSM program.



Drexel consults with employees on the conduct and development of process hazard analyses and on the development of other elements of the standard.



Drexel provides to employees and contractors, whose work is covered by the PSM program, ready access to PSM program files and documents upon request.



Drexel makes use of a PSM team comprised of employees and supervisors that actively engages in the implementation and management of the PSM program.





Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Drexel develops and implements written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process.  Operating procedures address the steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.  



Emergency Respon

se Program

A facility Emergency Action Plan is established to give direction to employees for safe response actions to be taken during fire and other emergencies. Potential chemical releases from the nitrogenous slow release plant food process and glyphosate formulation process are addressed in the Emergency Action Plan including notification procedures, evacuation procedures, and medical assistance procedures.  Production managers and supervisors are responsible for ensuring operating procedures for their processes are reviewed and updated at least annually and informing process operators of changes to operating procedures that affects their responsibilities.  Operating procedures are reviewed as often as necessary to ensure that they reflect current operating practices, including changes associated with process chemicals, technology, and equipment and changes to facilities.  Drexel certifies annually that operating procedures are current and accurate.  



Arrangements are established with the local emergency response agency, the fire department, and local hospital.



Drexel provides training to all employees when they are hired and before they begin their assignment. Employees receive training to familiarize themselves with all exits and evacuation routes.  An annual training session is conducted during a weekly safety meeting.



Evacuation drills are held at least once a year or when a change is made.  Drills are evaluated by the plant manager regarding effectiveness and timeliness.



After a drill, the plant manager judges the effectiveness of the plan and reviews any employee input concerning the drill.  Employees may identify something that requires a change to the procedure or was ineffective.  For example, they may discover new doors that would not open; they may enter storage closets instead of exits; or they may get lost and confused. 



The emergency action plan is reviewed with all employees, if any changes are made to the plan or if any employee r

esponsibilities change in the plan. 



Periodic compliance audits will ensure that the plan is kept up-to-date. 





Five Year Accident History

There has not been any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or MIPA during the last 5 years that caused any of the following:

? On-site death, injury, or significant property damage.

? Known offsite death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuation, or sheltering in place.
